body: When Medgar Evers College opened its doors in September 1971, Dr. Richard D. Trent, the school's first president, declared: ''I think a Yale man looking for a job in New York City will find he'd be better off with a degree from us.'' Eleven years later, the optimism has faded. Dr. Trent is no longer president and Medgar Evers is an institution in
title: A COLLEGE IN SEARCH OF A LEADER AND A PLACE IN THE COMMUNITY

body: When the Oceanfront Development Corporation, a local community organization in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, sought help to upgrade the Neptune Avenue commercial district last year, it contacted the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the voluntary charitable agency. The federation responded by helping the community group
title: CHARITABLE GROUP FIGHTS CITY DECAY

body: The Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn and St. John's Episcopal Hospital officially merged yesterday in an ecumenical effort to continue to provide health care to impoverished neighborhoods in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Crown Heights sections. The merger, which is believed to be the first in the state involving organized Jewish
title: HOSPITALS MERGE, JOINING 2 FAITHS IN DEPRIVED AREA

body: 60 Years at Beth Israel D r. Harold S. Douglas arrived at Beth Israel Hospital (now Medical Center) as a 24-year-old intern in 1922, became an attending pediatrician and has never left. Energetic at age 84, he has a bristling white mustache and favors bow ties and red-and-white checked shirts. Dr. Douglas met his wife, Harriet, at Beth Israel - a
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: As the staff at the Brooklyn Children's Museum was putting the finishing touches on its new exhibition, ''Discover Dolls: Reflections of Ourselves,'' several children sneaked in for their own preview. Ann Clausen let them think they were getting away with something while she watched their reactions. ''They read the labels!'' she said later.
title: 360-DOLLS-360 ON DISPLAY IN BROOKLYN

body: Rabbi Israel H. Levinthal, the spiritual leader of the Brooklyn Jewish Center in the Crown Heights section since 1919, died Sunday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 94 years old and resided in New Rochelle. Rabbi Levinthal, a descendant of generations of rabbis, had been elected by his congregation to a life term as its spiritual leader. In
title: Israel H. Levinthal, 94, Brooklyn Center Rabbi

body: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and charged with throwing a teenage Queens girl to her death from the roof of a 13-story building after raping her, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Barry Coker, 24 years old, of 328 Sterling Place, in the Crown Heights section, was arrested Friday and charged with second-degree murder in the Sept. 26 slaying
title: Brooklyn Man Arrested In Rape-Murder of Girl

body: Voluntary agencies and community groups all over New York City report marked increases in people who say they have no money for food. In poor neighborhoods and in relatively affluent ones, adults and children are lining up in growing numbers for bags of groceries or for hot meals ladled out at soup kitchens, according to officials for the groups.
title: HUNGER FOUND TO GRIP RISING NUMBER IN CITY

body: A judge yesterday ordered a rerun next Tuesday of two disputed Democratic primary races in Brooklyn - one for the House of Representatives and one for the State Assembly - after charges of voting fraud. The order for the two reruns, which was given by Acting Justice Eugene Berkowitz of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, threw out the Sept. 23
title: RERUNS ORDERED IN BROOKLYN FOR TWO DISPUTED ELECTIONS

body: Mario M. Cuomo brought his campaign for governor to two predominantly Jewish neighborhoods in Brooklyn yesterday, while Lewis E. Lehrman, his Republican opponent, also did some running - clocking a snappy 32 minutes and 20 seconds in the five-mile New York City Marathon computer run through Central Park. Mr. Lehrman, in a statement, criticized Mr.
title: LEHRMAN TAKES RACE TO PARK AS CUOMO GOES TO BROOKLYN

body: Touring Hasidic neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Lewis E. Lehrman, the Republican candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would freeze hiring by the state government ''for as long as it is necessary to get the budget under control.'' Earlier in the day, at a news conference in Manhattan, Mr. Lehrman turned back repeated queries as to whether he
title: LEHRMAN PROPOSES JOB FREEZE IN STATE GOVERNMENT

title: CITY VOTE FOR TOP STATE OFFICES BY ASSEMBLY DISTRICTS; DEMOCRATIC REPUBLICAN GOVERNOR GOVERNOR

body: Two former state senators with different political styles and backed by rival black political factions in central Brooklyn will face each other in next week's Democratic primary. The contest for the newly drawn 12th District resulted from the decision by Representative Shirley Chisholm not to seek re-election. The outcome is likely to determine not
title: 2 EX-STATE SENATORS VIE FOR REP. CHISHOLM'S JOB

body: EARLY last week, a delegation of five tenants from a three-building c omplex on St. Johns Place in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn wenti nto a local office of the Department of Housing Preservation and D evelopment to meet their new landlord: New York City. Their 50-unit complex was seized on Aug. 13 by the city in the first phase of a
title: NEW LAW REDUCES BROOKLYN TAX FORECLOSURES

body: Twenty-nine of 76 physicians whose medical education was subsidized by New York State in the last decade in return for practicing for a period later in medically underserved areas chose to repay their subsidies rather than fulfill their obligation, a legislative commission reported yesterday. The so-called ''buy-outs,'' it said, are one reason New
title: MANY DOCTORS PREFER 'BUY OUTS' TO REPAY SUBSIDIES FOR SERVICE

body: Provisions of the tax bill approved by Congress this week will make it possible to begin renovations by January on 4,200 dilapidated apartments in New York City, officials of the state and city said yesterday. The bill will also enable low- and moderate-income people to buy lower-priced cooperative apartments more easily. However, the officials
title: CITY'S HOUSING TO BENEFIT FROM NEW U.S. TAX BILL

body: Two men were fatally shot in separate incidents in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday morning. The body of Ronald Blakeney, 32 years old, of 883 Bergen Avenue, was found in the lobby of a building at 1661 St. Johns Place, and Neil Williams, 35, was slain about 20 blocks away, in front of his home at 641 Washington Avenue, the police
title: THE CITY; The Police Blotter

body: Competition among minority-group candidates could jeopardize the election of blacks in two Brooklyn Congressional districts that were redrawn to help their candidacies, according to some politicians. They say that black and Hispanic leaders should join in an effort to insure that the seats, in the new 11th and 12th Districts, are not lost to white
title: MINORITY DIVISIVENESS SEEN IN BROOKLYN RACES

body: The present city administration has never publicly acknowledged that its programs of tax incentives for the creation and rehabilitation of housing have fostered arson by rapacious landlords in a hurry for their tax and other rewards. But an unreleased report prepared by the city's own Arson Task Force confirms what everyone has known for a long
title: NEW YORK; ARSON AND J-51

body: Sources at the City University of New York said yesterday that the president of Medgar Evers College had asked for a sabbatical and reassignment to another institution within the system. The office of the president, Dr. Richard D. Trent, had been occupied for nearly three months by students who, along with faculty members and community residents,
title: EMBATTLED CHIEF AT EVERS COLLEGE REPORTED TO QUIT

body: An argument that erupted over a minor traffic accident in Brooklyn just before noon yesterday ended when one driver shot the other to death and then sped off, the police reported. According to the police, the two cars involved in the accident apparently brushed against each other as they were going down Brooklyn Avenue at President Street in the
title: BROOKLYN MISHAP ENDS IN KILLING

body: NEW CASTLE A remote corner of this community is decidedly suburban, but the language there is Yiddish. An 8-year-old boy politely but incredulously asks a visitor, ''You don't speak Yiddish?'' Then a younger boy on a banana-seat bicycle tears down the hill that is Tora Road, his peyos, or hair locks, flying in the wind. At the top of the hill is
title: HASIDIM FLOURISH IN SUBURBAN SETTING

body: A stage comedy, shadow puppets, dance and music are the fare of the Second Asian Summer Gala this weekend at Queens Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadow. The Pan Asian Repertory Theater will present Edward Sakamoto's comedy ''Yellow Is My Favorite Color'' today at 3 P.M. (free) and tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 3 and 8 ($7; $5 for students and the
title: WEEKENDER GUIDE; Friday; ASIA IN FLUSHING MEADOW

body: International Israel said it had destroyed the Syrian ground-to-air missile system in the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon. Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, in a broadcast interview, described the strikes as ''one of the most brilliant, complicated and intricate operations'' ever carried out by Israel and said they represented ''a turning point'' in
title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 10, 1982

body: To help students from minority groups qualify for medical careers, the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation has begun a $4 million program to provide education for hundreds of promising teen-agers in New York City and rural areas of Alabama. About 1,000 students will be enrolled in the next four years. The program will offer special training beginning with
title: 44 MILLION FOR MEDICAL CAREERS

body: The dancer and choreographer Bill T. Jones will give three free performances in Manhattan and Brooklyn this weekend. Today at 1:30 P.M., Mr. Jones will perform with members of his ensemble and advanced students of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Studio at the studio, 1515 Broadway, at 44th Street. Tomorrow at 3:30 and 4:30 P.M., Mr. Jones
title: Bill T. Jones to Give 3 Free Dance Programs

body: Over the last five years, the Borough Park section of Brooklyn has become one of the most ambitious centers of residential real estate activity in the city. According to specialists in property sales and mortgage loans, land prices have soared as contractors buy old frame houses on side streets off the main avenues, demolish them and build new
title: HOUSING SURGE ALTERS BOROUGH PARK

body: St. John's Episcopal Hospital and the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn announced yesterday that they would merge. They said they had reached agreement in an ecumenical effort to preserve medical care for predominately black and impoverished neighborhoods in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Crown Heights sections of northern Brooklyn. The
title: PLAN FOR MERGER SET IN BROOKLYN BY 2 HOSPITALS

body: AGENERAL contractor named Thomas Delmazio has his office on the c orner of 71st Street and 20th Avenue in the Bensonhurst section of B rooklyn. He has done apartment-renovation work in northern Flatbush a nd Coney Island, but not in Bensonhurst. That disappoints him as much as it surprises the visitor to Bensonhurst. Fully occupied apartments
title: REHABILITATION LAGS IN THE BETTER AREAS

body: The Los Angeles police will no longer use a choke hold that cuts off the air supply, Chief Daryl Gates said Thursday. Chief Gates said his department was dropping the bar-arm control hold and that he was recommending to the Police Commission that it no longer authorize use of that method. The Police Commission, the civilian panel that runs the
title: LOA ANGELES POLICE END USE OF CHOKE HOLD THAT STOPS AIR

body: A judge proposed a settlement last night in an effort to end a sitin by students at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn. The terms of the proposed settlement, which were not made public, were offered by Justice William Bellard of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to administrators of the college and representatives of the students occupying the offices
title: JUDGE OFFERS SETTLEMENTS FOR EVERS COLLEGE SIT IN

body: The takeover by students of the office of the president at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn this week was the culmination of weeks of protest. Students and faculty members say it is symptomatic of larger problems that have wedged a wall of animosity between many of them and the president. Dozens of students remained barricaded yesterday in the
title: MEDGAR EVERS COLLEGE PROTEST GROWS

body: The police were seeking three men yesterday in connection with the shooting of a rookie police officer during a chase in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn Saturday night. The wounded officer, Michael Maillie, 29 years old, was listed in good condition at Kings County Hospital with a bullet wound in the left thigh. A police spokesman, Fred
title: THE CITY; Rookie Officer Shot by Suspect

body: A rookie police officer was shot in the leg last night while chasing two holdup men in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said. The officer, 29-year-old Michael Maillie, was the second New York City officer to be wounded while chasing a suspect in three days. The other officer, William Wright, 42, was shot in the neck Thursday while
title: ROOKIE OFFICER SHOT IN LEG DURING CHASE OF 2 MEN IN HOLDUP

body: A New York City detective and a robbery suspect were wounded last night in an exchange of gunfire on a street corner in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the police said. The detective, William Wright, 42 years old, was hit once in the back of his neck during the shootout at Eastern Parkway and Ralph Avenue around 9 P.M., according to a police
title: WOUNDED DETECTIVE SHOOTS HIS ASSAILANT IN A STREET GUN DUEL

body: THIS is a tough year to look for an apartment or a house in New YorkC ity, but it is also a year of opportunity. The availability of r ental apartments remains low - the vacancy rate was 2.l3 percent at t he most recent count - and high mortgage rates are forcing up the c ost of cooperatives, condominiums and houses. But a b orough-byborough survey
title: A HOMESEEKER'S GUIDE TO THE CITY

body: Antoinette Rennick was walking to her home in Ozone Park, Queens, on the evening of Jan. 23 when a man jumped out of a Ford Thunderbird and attempted to steal her pocketbook. When the 38-year-old woman, who worked in a knitting mill, resisted, the man fatally stabbed her and sped away. Four days later, police officers in Brooklyn stopped Perry
title: CRIME UPDATE; PATTERN FOUND IN KNIFEPOINT ROBBERIES OF WOMEN

body: LIFE By LAURIE JOHNSTON On the door of the room he shares with his mother and her four younger children in Brooklyn, 16-year-old Vang Vuthy has printed ''Cambodian'' with pride and a red marker, crowning it with a familiar temple - probably the only Angkor Wat graffito in town. In the adjacent room is a brand-new American, Vutha Sam, born to
title: SOUTHEAST ASIAN REFUGEES IN BROOKLYN RENEWING STRUGGLE FOR A BETTER

body: PARKS are one of the few places where city dwellers can get a real sense of the seasonal changes that once directed human life. Most people seem to prefer to witness winter from behind a steamy apartment window. The parks seem deserted then, with only a few dog walkers and joggers to witness their bleak beauty and new serenity. But this Sunday,
title: SUNDAY WALK TO SCALE HEIGHTS OF PROSPECT PARK

John Sotomayor Search Continues for Possible Victims of Fire Firemen watching yesterday as a crane removed rubble from the tenement building at 258 Albany Avenue in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, in which seven persons were killed early Wednesday in a fire attributed to arson. At least one child was still unaccounted for yesterday.

body: A fire attributed to arson killed seven residents of a Brooklyn tenement early yesterday and injured 27 persons, 14 of them firemen. Fire Department officials said that the blaze, at 258 Albany Avenue in the Crown Heights section, had been set and that they had no suspects. Two persons died in a fire in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn shortly
title: 7 KILLED IN BROOKLYN TENEMENT; 2 DIE IN 2D BLAZE

body: International A major policy split on Poland's debts was reported in the Reagan Administration. High Pentagon officials said that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger intended to keep pressing to have Poland declared in default of its debts to the West and to prod Western European nations to halt their natural gas pipeline deal with Moscow. (Page
title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1982

body: While taking part in a program in which Rikers Island inmates are released for part of the day to clean Parks Department facilities, a prisoner walked into the men's room of a Brooklyn recreational center and ran out a back door. He was recaptured later in the day. The escape, which occurred at the St. John's Recreation Center, at 1251 Prospect
title: THE CITY; Work-Plan Inmate Flees and Is Seized

body: A $380,275 contract was awarded yesterday to a Queens construction company to make repairs on the Franklin Avenue Shuttle. The shuttle, which operates in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, was shut down last week because officials feared that a retaining wall holding up an elevated section of the line would collapse. The Petracca Construction
title: THE CITY; Concern to Repair Brooklyn Shuttle

body: Stepping gingerly to the center of a makeshift scaffold seven feet hi gh, and easing a roller soaked with white paint across a dingy br own area, Jesse Walls, a Rikers Island inmate, spoke yesterday ab out the work. He was painting a stairwell ceiling of St. John's Recreation Center in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section. ''For the corners I use
title: RIKERS PRISONERS FIND PRIDE IN WORK AT PARKS

body: The troubled Franklin Avenue Shuttle, once the gateway to Brooklyn's Ebbets Field, was shut down yesterday for emergency repairs after the Transit Authority said a street-level concrete retaining wall holding up a an elevated section of the subway line was in danger of collapse. Local residents expressed the fear that the emergency closing was the
title: FRANKLIN AVENUE SUBWAY SHUTTLE IN BROOKLYN IS CLOSED FOR REPAIRS

body: Most of the 18 campuses of the City University of New York lack proper security equipment, and the university's guards are seriously overextended, according to a report on security at the institution. The report stresses the difficulty of making the vast institution secure at a time when crime has become an overriding concern to New Yorkers.
title: CITY UNIVERSITY REPORT EMPHASIZES INADEQUATE SECURITY EQUIPMENT

body: Leftovers from other children's trays were fed yesterday to some of about 50 children in a Brooklyn elementary school who returned from winter vacation to find they were no longer e ligible for free hot lunches. Most of the se children had failed to return completed forms that are required under new Federal regulations to determine eligibility for
title: BROOKLYN PUPILS FED OTHERS' LUNCH LEFTOVERS
